author: The Australian
title: Nano cell project: art meets science to make the invisible visible
text:

GRAPHIC: How does Australia compare with the rest of the world?
QUIZ: How much do you really know about startups?
Armed with an Xbox game controller and an Oculus Rift virtual reality headset, 3D animator and artist John McGhee has found himself at the forefront of microbiology research and a world-first effort to put scientists inside human cells to “see” processes ­occurring in nano­scale, or one-billionth of a metre.
Already scientists and ani­maters have created “macro” three-dimensional virtual realities inside human bodies using data from MRI and CT scans in a process set to revolutionise how doctors examine and tell patients what is going on in their bodies.
Dr McGhee’s project at the Centre of Excellence for Convergent Bio-Nano Science and Technology takes it down to the cellular level, and in the first instance will focus on showing how acute pain becomes chronic inside cells. So far nano-biologists have worked in 2D environments delivered by superpowered microscopes, but with Dr McGhee’s help they will be able to examine cell processes from an angle that could lead to discoveries and new approaches to fighting diseases such as cancer and developing drug treatments.
Dr McGhee works at a size where it is impossible to “see” anything. “It really is just pea soup because it is beyond the wavelength of light,” he said.
However, using microscopic data he can reconstruct three-­dimensional cell struc­tures. The art is to make the picture comprehensible, using colours and textures to show different struc­tures.
“It is about making the invisible visible,” he said. “This is enabling scientists to see cells in a new way. They have been looking from the outside in but now they will be able to look from the inside out — who knows where that might lead.”
A former animator who worked on television commercials, Dr McGhee is now an academic at the University of NSW’s Art and Design centre, specialising in 3D visualisation. He was brought into the project by centre director Tom Davis, a nano scientist at Monash University who ­realised scientists needed artistic expertise and artistry to make their discoveries more accessible.
“Too often we preach to the converted when we are communicating science,” he said. “We hope to reach a vast number of people in a way that hasn’t been done before, all aimed at increasing people’s understanding of ­nanotechnology.”
Dr McGhee said the project was part of a trend for scientists to reach out to artists to help them visualise and explain huge amounts of data produced by scanners and computer processing. “We are in a renaissance age of collaboration between disciplines,” he said. However, when working with scientists he still felt like the “oddball character”, confessing he is not sure whether to wear jeans and T-shirt or don a white coat. “It does represent a wardrobe problem,” he joked.
